{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox games | Name = V British Empire and Commonwealth Games | Logo = Logo 1954 Vancouver.png | Size = 160 | Host city = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada | Optional caption = | Nations participating = 24 | Athletes participating = 662 | Events = 91 | Opening ceremony = 30 July | Closing ceremony = 7 August | Officially opened by = [[Earl Alexander of Tunis]] | Athlete's Oath = [[Bill Parnell]] | Officially closed by = [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|HRH the Duke of Edinburgh]] | Queen's Baton = | Stadium = [[Empire Stadium (Vancouver)|Empire Stadium]] | previous = [[1950 British Empire Games|IV]] | next = [[1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|VI]] }} The '''1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games''' were held in [[Vancouver]], British Columbia, Canada, from 30 July to 7 August 1954. These were the first games since the name change from [[British Empire Games]] took effect in 1952. It was at these games that the "Miracle Mile" took place between [[Roger Bannister]] and [[John Landy]] at [[Empire Stadium (Vancouver)|Empire Stadium]]. This was the first time these two (and at that time the only two) sub-[[four-minute mile]] runners appeared in the same race, and also the first time two runners broke four minutes in the same race. On the same afternoon, [[James Peters (athlete)|Jim Peters]], the holder of the world best time for the marathon, entered the stadium 17 minutes ahead of his nearest rival, but collapsed on his final lap, and never completed the race. The games were attended by 24 nations and 662 competitors.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecgf.com/games/intro.asp?yr=1954|title=Commonwealth Games Federation - 1954 Commonwealth Games - Introduction|last=|first=|date=|website=www.thecgf.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170615095819/http://thecgf.com/games/intro.asp?yr=1954|archive-date=15 June 2017|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-05-06|df=dmy-all}} ==Venues== *Opening and Closing Ceremonies, Athletics: [[Empire Stadium (Vancouver)|Empire Stadium]], [[Hastings Park]] *Bowls: West Point Grey Club, New West Club *Boxing: [[Vancouver Forum|Exhibition Forum]], [[Pacific National Exhibition]] *Cycling: Empire Oval (Track), 1155 East Broadway (Road) *Fencing: [[Lord Byng Secondary School|Lord Byng School]], [[West Point Grey]] *Rowing: [[Vedder Canal]], [[Chilliwack]] *Swimming and Diving: Empire Pool, [[University of British Columbia#Vancouver|University of British Columbia]], [[West Point Grey]] *Weightlifting: Exhibition Gardens, [[Pacific National Exhibition]] *Wrestling: [[Kerrisdale|Kerrisdale Arena]] *Athletes' Village: [[University of British Columbia#Vancouver|University of British Columbia]], [[West Point Grey]] ==Participating teams== [[Image:Commonwealth games 1954 countries map.PNG|thumb|250px|Countries that participated]] 24 teams were represented at the 1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games.

[[Honda Indy Edmonton]]| Round_No = 11th| Series = IndyCar Series| Location = [[Edmonton City Centre Airport]], [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], Canada| Course = Temporary street circuit| Course_mi = 1.973| Course_km = 3.154| Distance_laps = 95| Distance_mi = 187.435| Distance_km = 299.630| Weather = Temperatures reaching up to {{convert|27.5|C|F}},<ref name="Weather">{{cite web|title=''2010 Edmonton Indy'' weather information|url=https://www.almanac.com/weather/history/AB/Edmonton/2010-07-25|website=Old Farmer's Almanac|publisher=Yankee Publishing, Inc.|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref> with wind speeds up to {{convert|19.0|km/h|mph}}<ref name="Wind">{{cite web|title=Hourly Data Report for July 25, 2010|url=http://climate.weather.gc.ca/climate_data/hourly_data_e.html?timeframe=1&Year=2010&Month=7&Day=25&hlyRange=2004-04-07%7C2015-04-01&dlyRange=2005-01-21%7C2015-04-01&mlyRange=2005-05-01%7C2007-11-01&StationID=31427&Prov=AB&urlExtension=_e.html&searchType=stnProx&optLimit=specDate&StartYear=1840&EndYear=2018&selRowPerPage=25&Line=0&txtRadius=25&optProxType=navLink|website=Environment Canada|publisher=Government of Canada|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref> | Pole_Driver = [[Will Power]]| Pole_Team = [[Penske Racing|Team Penske]]| Pole_Time = 1:00.7126| Pole_Country = AUS| Fast_Driver = [[Scott Dixon]]| Fast_Team = [[Chip Ganassi Racing]]| Fast_Time = 1:02.1277| Fast_Lap = 88| Fast_Country = NZL | First_Driver = Scott Dixon| First_Team = Chip Ganassi Racing| First_Country = NZL | Second_Driver = Will Power| Second_Team = Team Penske| Second_Country= AUS | Third_Driver = [[Dario Franchitti]]| Third_Team = Chip Ganassi Racing| Third_Country = GBR | }} The '''2010 Honda Indy Edmonton''' was an [[INDYCAR|IndyCar]] motor race held on July 25, 2010 at the [[Edmonton City Centre (Blatchford Field) Airport|Edmonton City Centre Airport]], [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], Canada. It was the eleventh round of the [[2010 IndyCar Series season]], the third annual edition of the [[Edmonton Indy]] in the IndyCar Series, and the sixth anniversary running of the race (including three years on the [[Champ Car|Champ Car World Series]] (CCWS) schedule). The 95-lap race was won by [[Chip Ganassi Racing]] driver [[Scott Dixon]], who started from the third position. [[Will Power]] finished second for [[Team Penske]] and Dixon's teammate [[Dario Franchitti]] came in third.
Power, the defending champion of the Honda Indy Edmonton, won the [[pole position]] by posting the fastest lap in qualifying. In the race, Power maintained the first position throughout most of the event but was passed by teammate [[Hélio Castroneves]] with eighteen laps remaining. On the race's final restart on lap 92, Power attempted to reclaim the lead from Castroneves but the latter defended his position and was issued with a drive-through penalty. He chose not to take it and was demoted to tenth and the victory was awarded to Dixon.
There were four cautions and four lead changes among three different drivers during the race. It was Dixon's second win of the season, and the twenty-third of his career. The result meant Power extended his lead in the Drivers' Championship to 50 points over Franchitti, and 71 in front of Dixon, with six races of the season remaining.
==Report==
===Background=== [[File:Edmonton City Centre Airport.jpg|left|thumb|[[Edmonton City Centre (Blatchford Field) Airport|Edmonton City Centre Airport]], where the race was held.]] The Honda Indy Edmonton was confirmed as a part of the [[Indy Racing League]]'s (IRL) 2010 schedule for the IndyCar Series in December 2009 after [[Edmonton City Council]] voted to keep the race on the calendar despite incurring losses of $9.2 million over the previous two seasons.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/city-to-go-ahead-with-2010-indy-1.811518|title=City to go ahead with 2010 Indy|date=December 7, 2009|website=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC Edmonton]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160525064916/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/city-to-go-ahead-with-2010-indy-1.811518|archive-date=May 25, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> It would be the third consecutive year the race was held in the series, and the sixth Edmonton Indy counting the period from 2005 to 2007 when it was a [[Champ Car|Champ Car World Series]] (CCWS) event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.flagworld.com/news/2010/07/23/honda-indy-edmonton-preview/|title=Honda Indy Edmonton preview|date=July 23, 2010|website=Flag World|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150915190247/http://www.flagworld.com/news/2010/07/23/honda-indy-edmonton-preview/|archive-date=September 15, 2015|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> It would be the second consecutive round held in Canada, following the [[2010 Honda Indy Toronto|Honda Indy Toronto]] the previous week.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/sports/motor-sports/indycar-series-announces-2010-schedule|title=IndyCar Series announces 2010 schedule|date=July 31, 2009|work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160525044218/http://www.reviewjournal.com/sports/motor-sports/indycar-series-announces-2010-schedule|archive-date=May 25, 2016|access-date=May 24, 2016}}</ref> Tire supplier [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company|Firestone]] brought three types to tire to the race: two dry compounds (black-sidewall "Primary" and red-banded "Alternate") and grooved rain tires.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.motorsport.com/indycar/news/edmonton-firestone-racing-preview-2010-07-22/?s=1|title=Edmonton: Firestone Racing preview|date=July 22, 2010|website=[[motorsport.com]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604072251/http://www.motorsport.com/indycar/news/edmonton-firestone-racing-preview-2010-07-22/?s=1|archive-date=June 4, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref>
Prior to the race, [[Team Penske]] driver [[Will Power]] was the points leader with 377 points, with his primary championship rival [[Dario Franchitti]] 42 behind in second and [[Scott Dixon]] third. [[Ryan Briscoe]] was fourth on 292 points, and [[Ryan Hunter-Reay]] was sixth points adrift in fifth position.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race/2010_Honda_Indy_Toronto/O|title=2010 Honda Indy Toronto|website=Racing-Reference|publisher=USA Today Media Sports Group|access-date=May 24, 2016}}</ref> Having dominated the previous running of the Indy Edmonton, Power felt he could repeat the success and believed it would be "very competitive" in the qualifying session and "very tough" in the race.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.teampenske.com/news/index.cfm/i/469/38714/Team_Penske_Honda_Indy_Edmonton_Preview|title=Team Penske Honda Indy Edmonton Preview|date=July 21, 2010|website=[[Team Penske]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604072404/http://www.teampenske.com/news/index.cfm/i/469/38714/Team_Penske_Honda_Indy_Edmonton_Preview|archive-date=June 4, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> With seven races remaining in the season after the race (two on road courses and four on oval tracks), Franchitti said he wanted to get back into the championship battle after he retired with a gearbox problem in the [[2010 Iowa Corn Indy 250|Iowa Corn Indy 250]] and hoped he would perform well in Edmonton.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.edmontonjournal.com/sports/Franchitti+targets+another+title/3317191/story.html |title=Franchitti targets another title |last=Korobanik |first=John |date=July 24, 2010 |work=[[Edmonton Journal]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725210624/http://www.edmontonjournal.com/sports/Franchitti%2Btargets%2Banother%2Btitle/3317191/story.html |archive-date=July 25, 2010 |access-date=May 25, 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Practice and qualifying=== [[File:Will Power 2010 Indy 500 Practice Day 2.JPG|thumb|upright|Will Power had the sixth pole position of the 2010 season.]] Two practice sessions were held on the Friday before the race: each lasted for an hour. A third session, also an hour long, took place on the Saturday morning prior to qualifying.<ref name="schedule">{{cite web|title=Honda Indy Edmonton – Weekend Schedule|url=http://www.indycar.com/var/assets/11EdmontonFinal.pdf|work=IndyCar|accessdate=May 24, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820200002/http://www.indycar.com/var/assets/11EdmontonFinal.pdf|archivedate=August 20, 2010 }}</ref> Franchitti was fastest in the first practice session with a time of one minute and 3.0885 seconds; Dixon was second and Power third. [[Hélio Castroneves]] was fourth-fastest, ahead of [[Justin Wilson (racing driver)|Justin Wilson]] and [[Paul Tracy]]. [[Ryan Briscoe]], [[Ryan Hunter-Reay]], [[E. J. Viso]] and [[Takuma Sato]] rounded out the session's top-ten drivers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://classic.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/85471|title=Franchitti quickest in opening practice|last=Beer|first=Matt|date=July 23, 2010|website=[[Autosport]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603120137/http://classic.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/85471|archive-date=June 3, 2016|access-date=May 24, 2016}}</ref> The session was stopped twice: firstly for [[Milka Duno]] who lost control of her car and went into the turn ten tire barrier damaging her front wing, and then [[Bertrand Baguette]] spun after hitting a chicane kerb which caused to him to drive through an advertising billboard.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-drive/reviews/new-cars/indycar-racer-milka-duno-dangerous-not-up-to-speed/article1389595/|title=IndyCar racer Milka Duno dangerous, not up to speed|last=Bennett|first=Dean|date=July 25, 2010|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604073711/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-drive/reviews/new-cars/indycar-racer-milka-duno-dangerous-not-up-to-speed/article1389595/|archive-date=June 4, 2016|access-date=May 24, 2016}}</ref> In the second practice session, Power set the fastest time of the day with a lap of one minute and 1.6689 seconds, with his teammates Briscoe in second and Castroneves third. Franchitti recorded the fourth-quickest time; Sato was fifth and Dixon sixth. Wilson, Viso, Tracy and [[Tony Kanaan]] followed in the top ten.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://auto-racing.speedtv.com/article/indycar-power-tops-edmonton-practice|title=INDYCAR: Power Tops Edmonton Practice|last=Lewandoski|first=Dave|date=July 23, 2010|website=[[Speed (TV channel)|Speed]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726140911/http://auto-racing.speedtv.com/article/indycar-power-tops-edmonton-practice|archive-date=July 26, 2010|access-date=May 24, 2016}}</ref> Three [[Racing flags#Yellow flag|caution]] flags came out; Baugette crashed, Duno stalled after she spun and [[Tomas Scheckter]] slid into a tire barrier.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.racer.com/power-leads-penske-practice-sweep-at-edmonton/article/175262/|title=Power leads Penske practice sweep|date=July 23, 2010|website=racer.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729113717/http://www.racer.com/power-leads-penske-practice-sweep-at-edmonton/article/175262/|archive-date=July 29, 2010|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref>
In the final practice session, Castroneves recorded the fastest time with a lap of one minute and 1.6642 seconds, ahead of his Team Penske teammates Power and Briscoe. [[Hideki Mutoh]] recorded the fourth-fastest time; Dixon was fifth and Tracy sixth. Wilson was seventh-fastest, Kannan eighth, [[Marco Andretti]] ninth and Sato completed the top ten ahead of qualifying. Several drivers had high-speed spins without damaging their cars which triggered the caution flags to be displayed. A stoppage was caused when Tracy and [[Alex Tagliani|Alex Tagilani]] both spun in the first turn; Tracy narrowly avoided a collision with Baugette who was exiting the pit lane.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/85513|title=Penske blitzes final Edmonton session|last=Beer|first=Matt|date=July 24, 2010|website=Autosport|publisher=Haymarket Publications|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823223346/http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/85513|archive-date=August 23, 2010|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref>
Qualifying followed the usual road and street course system, with the field being split into two groups.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.f1network.net/main/s599/st127414.htm|title=New Road Course Qualifying Format|last=Cutler|first=Andrew|date=February 4, 2008|work=f1network.net|publisher=Durham Associates Group|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516231250/http://www.f1network.net/main/s599/st127414.htm|archive-date=May 16, 2008|accessdate=May 25, 2016}}</ref> All cars were split into two groups of twelve, with the fastest six from each group going through to the "Top 12" session. In this session, the fastest six runners progressed to the "Firestone Fast Six". The fastest driver in the final session claimed pole position, with the rest of the runners lining up in session order, regardless of qualifying times. (Fast Six from one to six, Top 12 from seven-twelve and Round 1 from 13–24, with Group 1 drivers occupying the odd-numbered [[Glossary of motorsport terms|grid]] positions, and Group 2 drivers occupying the even-numbered starting positions).<ref name=":2" /> Duno was prohibited from participating in qualifying because her practice lap times did not meet the required performance standards but was allowed to start the race.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/m/wp/blog.html?b=news.nationalpost.com/2010/07/24/irl-places-duno-on-probation-for-being-too-slow |title=IRL places Duno on probation for being too slow |date=July 24, 2010 |work=[[National Post]] |access-date=May 25, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6kXJgyxET?url=http://news.nationalpost.com/sports/irl-places-duno-on-probation-for-being-too-slow |archivedate=September 15, 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> In the first group of twelve runners, Power paced the session, nearly three-tenths of a second faster than teammate Briscoe with Castroneves in third place. Other drivers to make it into the second session of qualifying were Franchitti, Wilson and [[Raphael Matos]].<ref name=":7">{{cite web|url=http://www.indycar.com:8080/var/assets/indycar-results-quals-r1g16.pdf|title=Honda Indy Edmonton: Qualifying Round 1 – Group 1|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713030143/http://www.indycar.com:8080/var/assets/indycar-results-quals-r1g16.pdf|archive-date=July 13, 2011|work=IndyCar Series|accessdate=September 5, 2010}}</ref> The remaining twelve drivers took part in the second group, with [[Simona de Silvestro]] recording her fastest lap of the day. Hunter-Reay, Dixon, Viso, Mutoh and Scheckter were the other competitors in the top six, and thus progressed to the second round of qualifying.<ref name=":8">{{cite web|url=http://www.indycar.com:8080/var/assets/indycar-results-quals-r1g26.pdf|title=Honda Indy Edmonton: Qualifying Round 1 – Group 2|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713030149/http://www.indycar.com:8080/var/assets/indycar-results-quals-r1g26.pdf|archive-date=July 13, 2011|work=IndyCar Series|accessdate=September 5, 2010}}</ref> In the Top 12, Power set the fastest lap time, holding off teammate Castroneves and Dixon. Briscoe, Franchitti and Viso finished between fourth and sixth, and would be the other half of the drivers that progressed to the Fast Six.<ref name=":9">{{cite web|url=http://www.indycar.com:8080/var/assets/indycar-results-quals-r26.pdf|title=Honda Indy Edmonton: Qualifying – Top 12|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713030032/http://www.indycar.com:8080/var/assets/indycar-results-quals-r26.pdf|archive-date=July 13, 2011|work=IndyCar Series|accessdate=September 5, 2010}}</ref> Power clinched his sixth pole position of the season with a time of one minute and 00.7126 seconds. He was joined on the grid'<nowiki/>s front row by teammate Castroneves who had the pole position until Power's lap. [[Chip Ganassi Racing]] teammates Dixon and Franchitti were third and fourth, and Briscoe took fifth ahead of Viso.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2010/07/26/indycar-2010-honda-indy-edmonton-offers-a-view-to-a-thrill-spo/|title=IndyCar: 2010 Honda Indy Edmonton offers a view to a thrill|last=Filipponio|first=Frank|date=July 26, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729222346/http://www.autoblog.com/2010/07/26/indycar-2010-honda-indy-edmonton-offers-a-view-to-a-thrill-spo|archive-date=July 29, 2010|work=Autoblog|accessdate=May 24, 2016}}</ref>
===Race=== The drivers took to the track at 10:00 AM ([[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]−6) for a 30-minute warm-up session.<ref name=schedule/> Power maintained his good performance, setting a time of one minute and 1.8397 seconds. Dixon was the second-fastest driver. Power's Team Penske teammates Castroneves and Briscoe rounded out the top four.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.motorsport.com/indycar/news/edmonton-warmup-times-2/?s=1|title=Edmonton: Warmup times|date=July 25, 2010|website=motorsport.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604072713/http://www.motorsport.com/indycar/news/edmonton-warmup-times-2/?s=1|archive-date=June 4, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref>
The race began at 4:00 p.m. local time,<ref name=schedule/> and was televised live in the United States on [[Versus (TV channel)|Versus]]. Weather conditions at the start of the race were sunny and mild with an air temperature between {{convert|76|-|78|F|C}} and a track temperature which ranged between {{convert|102|-|111|F|C}}.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.motorsport.com/indycar/news/edmonton-firestone-racing-race-report/?s=1|title=Edmonton: Firestone Racing race report|date=July 26, 2010|website=motorsport.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604072813/http://www.motorsport.com/indycar/news/edmonton-firestone-racing-race-report/?s=1|archive-date=June 4, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref><ref name="hondarace">{{Cite web|url=http://news.honda.com/newsandviews/article.aspx?id=5558-en|title=Honda Indy Edmonton Race Report|date=July 27, 2010|website=[[Honda]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604072908/http://news.honda.com/newsandviews/article.aspx?id=5558-en|archive-date=June 4, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> Power maintained his pole position advantage heading into the first turn. Duno spun off the track at the start but no caution was needed.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.crash.net/indycar/race-report/163382/1/helio-fumes-as-penalty-hands-win-to-dixon.html|title=Scott Dixon wins in Edmonton|date=July 25, 2010|website=crash.net|page=1|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151030021110/http://www.crash.net/indycar/race-report/163382/1/helio-fumes-as-penalty-hands-win-to-dixon.html|archive-date=October 30, 2015|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> De Silvestro passed Viso for sixth place on the same lap.<ref name=":3" /> At the end of the first lap, Power led Castroneves, with Dixon, Franchitti, Briscoe, de Silvestro, Viso, Hunter-Reay, Wilson and Matos rounding out the top ten.<ref name="Lapchart">{{cite web|url=http://www.indycar.com/var/assets/indycar-race-lapchart.pdf|title=Sao Paulo Indy 300: Race Lap Chart|date=July 25, 2010|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|work=IndyCar Series|accessdate=May 25, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605130852/http://www.indycar.com/var/assets/indycar-race-lapchart.pdf|archivedate=June 5, 2011 }}</ref> The top five drivers began to pull away from the rest of the field. On lap two, Tracy made contact with Matos' rear-end in turn two who was sent spinning into the infield grass and Matos drove cautiously to the pit lane with a flat left-rear tire. Scheckter's front wing was damaged on lap 10 for which he made a [[pit stop]] for a replacement nose cone.<ref name=":4" /> After starting fifteenth, Tracy drove aggressively and moved up into tenth position by the 20th lap.<ref name=":3" />
[[File:Scott Dixon - 2011 Baltimore Grand Prix.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Scott Dixon ''(pictured in 2011)'' won the race after [[Hélio Castroneves]] was demoted for blocking Will Power.]]
Briscoe passed the Chip Ganassi Racing drivers after they were held up by slower cars to move into second place on lap 29. [[Racing flags#Green flag|Green-flag]] pit stops began four laps later. Wilson spun at the end of the backstretch while braking for turn ten on the 36th lap after his right-rear shock absorber failed and drove slowly to his pit box to repair damage to his vehicle. [[Danica Patrick]] attempted to pass Baugette around the [[Racing line|inside]] on lap 39, but lost control of her car and ran wide into the infield grass section and rejoined the track in 17th without damaging her [[Suspension (vehicle)|suspension]]. Andretti's front wing came apart on lap 46 while holding up four cars, and Scheckter ran wide as the four cars passed Andretti. The first full course caution of the event was necessitated on the following lap when [[Alex Lloyd (racing driver)|Alex Lloyd]] spun into the grass and [[Stall (engine)|stalled]] his engine. Andretti made a pit stop for a replacement front wing during the caution. Racing resumed at the start of lap 51 with Power leading Castroneves, Briscoe and Dixon. Shortly afterward, de Silvestro was hit from behind by Viso who overheated his brakes, and went into the turn one tyre barrier, causing the second caution. Viso avoided making contact with teammate Tracy (who took avoiding action) on the same lap.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
Viso was issued with a drive-through penalty and rejoined in tenth position. The race resumed on lap 54 with Power retaining his lead. The race's third caution was issued shortly after the restart when Kanaan made light contact with the side of Tagilani who spun. [[Mario Romancini]] was blinded by smoke that came from the incident and was hit by the recovering Tagilani. Both cars sustained heavy damage and retired but Kanaan was able to continue without apparent damage. Power led the field back up to speed at the lap-58 [[Rolling start|restart]]. Briscoe fell behind the two Chip Ganassi Racing drivers, while Tracy moved past Hunter-Reay for sixth place. The second (and final) round of green-flag pit stops started on the 63rd lap; Tracy and Hunter-Reay made their pit stops over the next five laps in the hope a caution flag would be shown that would allow the pair to lead the race.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> After the pit stops, Power remained in the first position,<ref name=":4" /> and had the Alternate tires fitted on his car.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.crash.net/indycar/race-report/163382/2/helio-fumes-as-penalty-hands-win-to-dixon.html|title=Scott Dixon wins in Edmonton|date=July 25, 2010|website=crash.net|page=2|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160525134206/http://www.crash.net/indycar/race-report/163382/2/helio-fumes-as-penalty-hands-win-to-dixon.html|archive-date=May 25, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> He was ahead of Castroneves and Dixon.<ref name="Lapchart" />
On the 77th lap, Power and teammate Castroneves (on the Primary tires) encountered slower cars, and the latter took advantage of the situation which allowed him to overtake Power for the lead. Castroneves began to pull away from Power. Ten laps later, de Silvestro's car ran out of fuel and pulled over to the side of the track onto the infield grass to retire from the race which prompted the fourth (and final) caution. Racing resumed when the [[Safety|pace car]] drove into the pit lane at the start of lap 92. Power went onto the outside lane at the entrance of the first turn, and Castroneves drove left as a blocking manoeuvre. Castroneves accelerated out of the corner's exit which caused Power to run wide. Dixon took advantage of the situation and passed Power around the outside to take over second place.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" /> The move was immediately reviewed by the IndyCar chief steward and competition president [[Brian Barnhart]], which led to Castroneves being shown a black-flag a minute later as he was deemed as having blocked Power.<ref name=":6"/> Castroneves was informed that he was issued with a drive-through penalty, but opted to remain on the track for the final two laps and crossed the start-finish line first on the road.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/racing/racing/indycar/columns/story?id=5410635&columnist=oreovicz_john|title=IndyCar Series gripped by controversy|last=Oreovicz|first=John|date=July 27, 2010|website=[[ESPN]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160525125555/http://espn.go.com/racing/racing/indycar/columns/story?id=5410635&columnist=oreovicz_john|archive-date=May 25, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref>
Because Castroneves had not taken his penalty, the victory was awarded to Dixon,<ref name=":6" /> with Power in second and Franchitti third. Briscoe was fourth, and Hunter-Reay held off Tracy to claim fifth. Moraes, Viso and Sato finished in positions seven to nine, while Castroneves was demoted to tenth.<ref name="Lapchart" /> There were four cautions and four lead changes among three different drivers during the race.<ref name=edmontonindy>{{Cite web|url=http://racing-reference.info/race/2010_Honda_Indy_Edmonton/O|title=2010 Honda Indy Edmonton|website=Racing-Reference|publisher=USA Today Media Sports Group|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> It was Dixon's second win of the season, and the twenty-third of his career.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottdixon.com/biography|title=Scott Dixon – Biography|website=ScottDixon.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313215134/http://www.scottdixon.com/biography|archive-date=March 13, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref>
===Post-race=== [[File:Helio Castroneves 2010 Indy 500 OWAS.JPG|thumb|upright|Hélio Castroneves was demoted to tenth after he was judged to have blocked Will Power.]]
Castroneves was upset about the penalty and leapt from his car and yelled in anger at the flagman (looking for an explanation) and grabbed the Head of Security Charles Burns as he sought an answer. He argued that he did not change his line: "I actually gave him room outside. When you go side by side like that with your teammate and the guy [Barnhart] has just swept ... literally, literally just takes it away from you ... it's just absurd."<ref name=":6" /> Castroneves was fined $60,000 by the IRL for "unsportsmanlike conduct" and was placed on probation for the rest of the season. It was later revealed by IndyCar CEO [[Randy Bernard]] that the series considered suspending Castroneves but chose not to because of his popularity with its fanbase.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2010/08/castroneves_fined_60000_by_ind.html|title=Castroneves fined $60,000 by IndyCar but avoids suspension|date=August 2, 2010|work=[[The Birmingham News|Birmingham News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811133201/http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2010/08/castroneves_fined_60000_by_ind.html|archive-date=August 11, 2010|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> Castroneves later apologized for his actions but still did not agree with the penalty.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/motor/irl/2010-07-26-helio-castroneves-apology_N.htm|title=Helio Castroneves apologizes for Edmonton tirade|date=July 26, 2010|website=[[USA Today]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703033020/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/motor/irl/2010-07-26-helio-castroneves-apology_N.htm|archive-date=July 3, 2015|access-date=May 25, 2016|agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref> Comparisons were made between Castroneves' block and his manoeuvre against Wilson in the [[2008 Detroit Indy Grand Prix]].<ref name=":6" /> Gordon Kirby of ''[[Motor Sport (magazine)|Motor Sport Magazine]]'' opined that Castroneves' move was fair and sportsmanlike and noted that several fans perceived it as "good, hard racing".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.motorsportmagazine.com/opinion/indycar/castroneves-ruling-bad-indycar|title=Castroneves ruling bad for IndyCar|last=Kirby|first=Gordon|date=August 3, 2010|work=[[Motor Sport (magazine)|Motor Sport]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604073401/http://www.motorsportmagazine.com/opinion/indycar/castroneves-ruling-bad-indycar|archive-date=June 4, 2016|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref>
Dixon said of his victory: "It's not a way you want to win for sure. When I win, I want to win being faster or putting a good pass on someone. But the way our season is going, I'll be taking anything at the moment."<ref name=":10">{{Cite news|url=http://www.torontosun.com/sports/columnists/terry_jones/2010/07/26/14825806.html|title=Unexpected ending to Edmonton Indy|last=Jones|first=Terry|date=July 26, 2010|work=[[Toronto Sun]]|access-date=May 26, 2016}}</ref> Second-place finisher Power said it was still a good finish for him in terms of scoring points.<ref name=":10" /> Tony Cotman, the circuit's design consultant, announced in February 2011 that the track would be improved and lengthened for that year. He stated that the layout of the track be moved to.the Eastern runway of the City Centre Airport in an attempt to create more excitement. The result of the alterations would be an additional {{convert|0.3|mi|km}} of track, creating a {{convert|2.2|mi|km|adj=on}} circuit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/edmonton-reveals-new-indy-course-31023.html|title=Edmonton Reveals New Indy Course|last=Panzariu|first=Ovidiu|date=February 10, 2011|website=Auto Evolution|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016235751/http://www.autoevolution.com/news/edmonton-reveals-new-indy-course-31023.html|archive-date=October 16, 2015|access-date=May 26, 2016}}</ref> With his second-place finish, Power extended his points lead in the standings to 50 over Franchitti and 71 ahead of Dixon. Briscoe and Hunter-Reay retained fourth and fifth positions.<ref name="edmontonindy" />

{{refimprove|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = 2012 [[Mr. Olympia]] | logo = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | genre = [[Professional bodybuilding]] competition | begins = September 27, 2012 | ends = September 30, 2012 | venue = [[Las Vegas Convention Center]] and [[Orleans Arena]] | location = [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] | coordinates = | country = United States | last = | prev = [[2011 Mr. Olympia]] | next = [[2013 Mr. Olympia]] | participants = | attendance = | organized = [[International Federation of BodyBuilders|IFBB]] | website = }} The '''2012 [[Mr. Olympia]]''' contest was an [[International Federation of BodyBuilders|IFBB]] [[professional bodybuilding]] competition and the feature event of '''Joe Weider's Olympia Fitness & Performance Weekend 2012''' held September 27–30, 2012 at the [[Las Vegas Convention Center]] and [[Orleans Arena]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]]. It was the 48th Mr. Olympia competition. Other events at the exhibition included the [[2012 212 Olympia Showdown|212 Olympia Showdown]], [[2012 Ms. Olympia|Ms. Olympia]], [[Fitness Olympia]], and [[Figure Olympia]] contests. The documentary film [[Generation Iron]] was filmed while following several Olympia contestants as they prepared for this competition. ==Results== A total prize pool of $650,000 was awarded. {| class="wikitable" ! Place ! Prize ! Name ! Country ! 1+2 ! 4 ! Points |- | 1 | $250,000{{cite web|url=http://www.ifbbpro.com/news/olympia-prize-money/|title=OLYMPIA PRIZE MONEY HITS ALL-TIME HIGH|date=July 16, 2012|publisher=ifbbpro.com|accessdate=15 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114182531/http://www.ifbbpro.com/news/olympia-prize-money/|archive-date=2012-11-14|dead-url=yes|df=}} | [[Phil Heath]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |5 |5 |10 |- | 2 | $100,000 | [[Kai Greene]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |10 |10 |20 |- | 3 | $75,000 | [[Shawn Rhoden]] |{{flagicon|Jamaica}} |15 |16 |31 |- | 4 | $50,000 | [[Dexter Jackson (bodybuilder)|Dexter Jackson]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |20 |20 |40 |- | 5 | $40,000 | [[Branch Warren]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |25 |31 |56 |- | 6 | $30,000 | [[Dennis Wolf]] |{{flagicon|Germany}} |35 |24 |59 |- | 7 | $18,000 | [[Toney Freeman]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |30 |34 |64 |- | 8 | $17,000 | [[Evan Centopani]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |42 |40 |82 |- | 9 | $16,000 | [[Johnnie O. Jackson]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |45 |46 |91 |- | 10 | $14,000 | [[Lionel Beyeke]] |{{flagicon|France}} |51 |52 |103 |- | 11 | $4,000 | [[Ben Pakulski]] |{{flagicon|Canada}} |54 |55 |109 |- | 12 | $4,000 | [[Roelly Winklaar]] |{{flagicon|Netherlands}} |62 |62 |124 |- | 13 | $4,000 | [[Ronny Rockel]] |{{flagicon|Germany}} |63 |67 |130 |- | 14 | $4,000 | [[Essa Obaid (bodybuilder)|Essa Obaid]] |{{flagicon|UAE}} |72 |65 |137 |- | 15 | $4,000 | [[Hidetada Yamagishi]] |{{flagicon|Japan}} |74 |75 |149 |- | 16 | $2,000 | [[Bill Wilmore]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |74 |76 |150 |- | 17 | $2,000 | [[Baitollah Abbaspour]] |{{flagicon|Iran}} |80 |80 |160 |- | 17 | $2,000 | [[Fred Smalls (bodybuilder)|Fred Smalls]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |80 |80 |160 |- | 17 | $2,000 | [[Michael Kefalianos]] |{{flagicon|Greece}}
{{flagicon|Australia}} |80 |80 |160 |} ==Notable events== *[[Phil Heath]] won his second consecutive IFBB Mr. Olympia title {{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1352750-mr-olympia-2012-results-winners-complete-events-recap-more|title=Mr. Olympia 2012 Results: Winners, Complete Events Recap & More|date=September 30, 2012|work=bleacherreport.com}} *[[Kai Greene]] placed second, his best ever showing after finishing third in the [[2011 Mr. Olympia]] contest *[[Evan Centopani]] placed eighth in his Mr. Olympia debut *[[Toney Freeman]], at the age of 46 years, finished in seventh place *[[Jay Cutler (bodybuilder)|Jay Cutler]], four-time Mr. Olympia, could not compete after undergoing surgery for a torn left bicep ==See also== * [[2012 Ms. Olympia]] * [[2012 212 Olympia Showdown]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.mrolympia.com Mr. Olympia] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0678zHA5dUU 2012 Mr. Olympia Judging Finals (Video)] {{Mr. Olympia}} [[Category:2012 in Nevada]] [[Category:Mr. Olympia| 2012]] [[Category:2012 in American sports]] [[Category:Sports in Las Vegas|Mr. Olympia 2012]] [[Category:2012 in bodybuilding]]
